div.p: Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent

M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 2 / 24
M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 3 / 24
A toy example illustrating rent-or-buy paradigms
A skier At the beginning of each day may
either rent skis for p, or buy them for s p.
At the end of the day, may break legs and skis
Input: the leg-breaking day Goal: find a cheapest strategy
M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 4 / 24
A toy example illustrating rent-or-buy paradigms

M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 4 / 24
Best deterministic online algorithm: rent for s 1 days and buy on day s. This strategy is (2 1s )-competitive
Best randomized online algorithm (chooses a random day from {1, . . . , s} and then buys on this day) is ee1 1.58-competitive
M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 5 / 24
Many problems exhibit the same rent-or-buy structure as SRP, e.g.
Bahncard problem (Fleischer, COCOON 98) (Karlin, Kenyon, Randall, STOC 01)
TCP Acknowledgement problem (Dooly, Goldman, Scott, JACM 01) (Karlin, Kenyon, Randall, STOC 01)
Page replication problem (Black, Sleator, CMU TR 89) (Albers, Koga, SWAT 94)
M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 6 / 24

What if rental price p may change each day?
(BUT: the purchase price = s rental price)

Results Upper Bound for Known Game End
In real life, there are two types of people:
Those, who buy shares because their price is rising Those, who buy shares because their price is falling down
Apparently, we may learn from both types!
M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 13 / 24
Results Upper Bound for Known Game End

M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 14 / 24
Results Upper Bound for Known Game End
Designing an optimal online algorithm for KGE, cont.
Has two thresholds A < B. It buys if the rental price falls outside [A, B]. If the rental price remains within [A, B], then it buys after s days.
PROT run on a sequence of length = sy , comp. ratio R = O(sL(y ))
For = s, PROT chooses A = s1/3 and B = s2/3.
M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 15 / 24
Results Upper Bound for Known Game End
Designing an optimal online algorithm for KGE, cont.
Has two thresholds A < B. It buys if the rental price falls outside [A, B]. If the rental price remains within [A, B], then it buys after s days.
PROT run on a sequence of length = sy , comp. ratio R = O(sL(y ))
For = s, PROT chooses A = s1/3 and B = s2/3.
M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 15 / 24
Results Upper Bound for Known Game End
For Known End Scenario with = s, PROT is O(s1/3)-competitive. (Recall that in this case A = s1/3, B = s2/3).
If the rental price remains in [A, B] for s steps, then the competitive ratio is O(B/A) = O(s1/3). (Almost normal ski-rental process).
If the price stays first within [A, B] and drops below A at some point, then PROT is O(s1/3)-competitive. (Proof omitted).
M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 16 / 24
Results Upper Bound for Known Game End
For Known End Scenario with = s, PROT is O(s1/3)-competitive. (Recall that in this case A = s1/3, B = s2/3).
If the rental price remains in [A, B] for s steps, then the competitive ratio is O(B/A) = O(s1/3). (Almost normal ski-rental process).
If the price stays first within [A, B] and drops below A at some point, then PROT is O(s1/3)-competitive. (Proof omitted).
M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 16 / 24
Results Upper Bound for Known Game End
If the price stays first within [A, B] and exceeds B at time k , then PROT is O(s1/3)-competitive.
Case 1. OPT buys skis till day k + B/2. PROT OPT
k B + s B s A = O(B/A) = O(s

M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 18 / 24
Results Upper Bound for Stochastic Game End

On a sequence of length s, PROT with thresholds A = s1/3 and B = s2/3 is O(s1/3)-competitive. What if we run PROT with these thresholds on sequence of arbitrary, unknown length ? Then PROT is R = O(s1/3 (1 + s/))-competitive!
We do not know , but we know that is geometricaly distributed and E[] = .
Solution: run PROT with A and B suited for . For = s, we get E[R] = O(s1/3 s log ) = O(s1/3 log s). (The same (log s)-approximation result for different ).
M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 19 / 24
Results Upper Bound for Stochastic Game End

In general, in SGE with parameter , E[R] = RPROT() log s.

Yes! Problem with geometric (and with uniform) distribution: it is very likely that the game ends much earlier than . Solution: assume the game ends at /(log s)1/3 and run PROT with appropriate thresholds A and B. Result: E[R] = RPROT() (log s)7/9.
M. Bienkowski (University of Wrocaw) Price Fluctuations: To Buy or to Rent 20 / 24
